elements.content: The synthesis of five new silver­(I) NHC complexes, bearing alkylenebimpy ligands with bridge lengths ranging from ethylene to hexylene is described. Their solid-state structures exhibit an unforeseen variety, including infinite strands of Ag3 units within a helically wound ligand environment. The very first infinite chain of almost linear Ag3 units within a cage of helically wound ligand molecules is described. All complexes are spectroscopically characterized and emit polychromatic blue light (420 nm ≤ λ ≤ 510 nm) after laser excitation at λ = 337 nm. This latter behavior might lead to applications in the field of organic light-emitting diodes.

elements.content: The development of the field of silver­(I) NHC complexes has been spurred by the seminal work of Lin and Wang, who reported on the synthesis of silver­(I) NHC complexes starting from Ag2O and the respective imidazolium salts. Since then, a large number of mono- and multidentate silver­(I) NHC complexes, which comprise a large structural diversity, have been synthesized (Figure ). Silver­(I) NHC complexes have found widespread use not only as carbene transfer reagents to generate NHC complexes of various transition metals but also as catalysts or as antimicrobials and metallo-drugs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The development of the field of silver(I) NHC complexes has been spurred by the seminal work of Lin and Wang, who reported on the synthesis of silver(I) NHC complexes starting from Ag2O and the respective imidazolium salts. Since then, a large number of mono- and multidentate silver(I) NHC complexes, which comprise a large structural diversity, have been synthesized (Figure ). Silver(I) NHC complexes have found widespread use not only as carbene transfer reagents to generate NHC complexes of various transition metals but also as catalysts or as antimicrobials and metallo-drugs.

elements.content: Examples of silver­(I) N-heterocyclic carbene complexes of various compositions. (A) [AgL2]+X–-type silver­(I) NHC complex. (B) [LAgX]-type and (C) [L2AgX]-type complexes with monocarbene ligands. (D) Trinuclear silver­(I) NHC complex bearing biscarbene ligands. (E) Trinuclear silver­(I) NHC complex stabilized with two methylenebimpy ligands.
elements.clean_text: 1  Examples of silver(I) N-heterocyclic carbene complexes of various compositions. (A) [AgL2]+X--type silver(I) NHC complex. (B) [LAgX]-type and (C) [L2AgX]-type complexes with monocarbene ligands. (D) Trinuclear silver(I) NHC complex bearing biscarbene ligands. (E) Trinuclear silver(I) NHC complex stabilized with two methylenebimpy ligands.

elements.content: Besides these applications, the use of stable, photoluminescent silver­(I) NHC complexes as light emitters for the manufacture of organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) is of high current interest. Since the photoluminescence of silver­(I) NHCs has first been observed by Lin and co-workers in 2002, various examples of photoluminescent silver­(I) NHCs have been reported (Figure ). In most cases, the emission spectra are dominated by ligand-centered transitions, allowing for tuning the emission by carefully altering the substitution pattern and hence the electronic structure of the ligands. Especially, substituents bearing N-donor functions, e.g. pyridine, have been shown to greatly influence the emission characteristics of silver­(I) NHCs. Moreover, it has been found for coinage metal NHC complexes in general that, upon aggregation of the complexes, metal–metal interactions lead to a metal-centered transition to the emission spectra. Naturally, these metal–metal interactions are more likely to occur when multidentate ligands are used. Such multidentate ligands often help to place the metal centers in close proximity toward each other.

elements.content: One ligand set, which combines both N-functional substituents and multidenticity, is the tetradentate (1,1′-bis­(N-pyrid-2-yl)-3,3′-alkylene)­bisimida­zol-2,2′-diylidene (alkylenebimpy) ligand. Recently, ligands of this type have been used for the synthesis of complexes containing group 8–10 metals, as well as complexes containing group 11 metals, namely, copper­(I) and silver­(I). While all but one of the group 8–10 metals yielded mononuclear complexes, exclusively multinuclear species were found for copper­(I) and silver­(I), containing up to four interacting metal centers, that are arranged in either a linear or a trigonal fashion and stabilized by two units of the methylenebimpy ligand (Figure E). However, neither their structural chemistry nor their photoluminescent properties have been examined exhaustively.

elements.content: Spurred by recent advances regarding the tunability of light-emitting complexes and the polynuclear structure of complex 4a, we became interested in the evaluation of the basic photoluminescent properties of silver­(I) NHC complexes of bimpy-type ligands with different chain lengths of the bridging alkylene unit.

elements.content: Bisimidazolium salts 3a–f, used as ligand precursors, bear bridging alkylene chains that range from methylene to hexylene units. They are synthesized according to a previously published procedure from pyrid-2-ylimidazol and the respective α,ω-dibromoalkanes and subsequent anion exchange with NH4PF6 (Scheme and the ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Bisimidazolium salts 3a-f, used as ligand precursors, bear bridging alkylene chains that range from methylene to hexylene units. They are synthesized according to a previously published procedure from pyrid-2-ylimidazol and the respective α,ω-dibromoalkanes and subsequent anion exchange with NH4PF6 (Scheme  and the ).

elements.content: Starting from these precursors, the silver­(I) NHC complexes 4a–f are synthesized following the general protocol used by Chen et al. for the methylene bridged compound 4a. Only slight modifications regarding the reaction conditions have been applied. An acetonitrile solution of the corresponding bisimidazolium salts 3b–f is reacted with Ag2O at 60 °C. After removal of excess Ag2O, the pure products 4b–f are precipitated by addition of diethyl ether as colorless to off-white solids in good yields and high purity (Scheme ).

elements.content: All compounds are characterized by elemental analysis, mass spectrometry, NMR spectrometry, UV/vis spectroscopy, and X-ray crystallography. The 1H NMR spectra of complexes 4b–f support the formation of the envisioned NHC complexes by the absence of any signals around δ = 10 ppm attributable to the acidic protons at the C2 position of the imidazolium moieties. The observed 13C NMR resonances around δ = 182 ppm are also indicative for silver­(I) carbene complexes.

The 1H NMR spectra of complexes 4b-f support the formation of the envisioned NHC complexes by the absence of any signals around δ = 10 ppm attributable to the acidic protons at the C2 position of the imidazolium moieties. The observed 13C NMR resonances around δ = 182 ppm are also indicative for silver(I) carbene complexes.

elements.content: The influence of the ligands’ bridge length is reflected in the chemical shift of the backbone proton resonances of the imidazolin-2-ylidene units. While in complexes 4a and 4c both signals attributed to these protons exhibit a similar chemical shift with a difference of merely 0.1 ppm, this separation is found to be more prominent for the complexes 4f (Δ = 0.46 ppm), 4b (Δ = 0.45 ppm), 4d (Δ = 0.40 ppm), and 4e (Δ = 0.35 ppm). Furthermore, there are significant differences in the observed shifts of the pyridyl units’ ortho-proton resonances. While these protons resonate at δ = 7.97 ppm or above in the case of 4a and 4c–4f, the protons of 4b are shifted upfield to δ = 7.68 ppm. This observation can be explained by stronger Ag–N interactions in 4b. Moreover, the appearance of the 1H NMR spectra, which show only a single set of resonances, allows for the assumption of symmetrical complex geometries, at least in solution.

elements.content: In order to gain more detailed information on the structure of complexes 4b–f, single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis have been grown by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into a solution of the respective compound in acetonitrile.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

In order to gain more detailed information on the structure of complexes 4b-f, single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis have been grown by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into a solution of the respective compound in acetonitrile.

elements.content: X-ray analysis of 4b reveals the formation of Ag3 moieties in the solid state. In contrast to the known structure of 4a, the arrangement of the silver cations is not trigonal with silver–silver interactions between all three silver cations; instead, it is almost linear with a Ag1–Ag3–Ag2 bond angle of 173.637(3)° and silver–silver distances of 2.9574(5) and 2.9506(5) Å, respectively. These distances are comparable to silver–silver distances found for other silver­(I) NHC complexes.

These distances are comparable to silver-silver distances found for other silver(I) NHC complexes.

elements.content: Moreover, they are significantly shorter than the sum of the atoms’ van der Waals radii, which is indicative for strong argentophilic interactions. Each of the Ag3 units is generally coordinated by the hemispheres of four different ligand molecules (Figure , schematically in Scheme ). Hereby, the central silver center is 5-fold coordinated by two pyridyl units of two different ligand molecules, one molecule of acetonitrile, and its two adjacent silver atoms in a strongly distorted trigonal-bipyramidal fashion. Each of the two terminal silver atoms is coordinated by the central silver atom, one carbene belonging to one of the pyridine donors at the central silver atom, and one set of carbene and pyridyl donor belonging to another ligand molecule. At both silver atoms, the carbenes are oriented trans to each other with C–Ag–C bond angles of 178.448(6)° and 177.887(6)°, respectively. The bond lengths of the Ag–C bonds fall in the range of 2.0927(1)–2.1064(2) Å, which is consistent not only with the bond lengths found in 4a but also with Ag–C distances reported earlier for various silver NHC complexes.

elements.content: The coordination mode of the ligand molecules distributing their four donor positions between two adjacent Ag3 units leads to an indefinite, helical strand that extends along the crystals’ y axis. Within this strand, adjacent Ag3 units are tilted against each other by approximately 120°, being only 3.5017(2) Å apart from each other. Hence, argentophilic interactions are present between adjacent Ag3 units as well.

elements.content: A similar structure was found for complex 4d. Although the principal coordination mode of the ligand is the same, there are distinct differences in the resulting crystal structure. As it was in the case for 4b, bent Ag3 units have been formed, which are similarly coordinated by ligand molecules, leading to a helically wound, indefinite strand along the crystals’ b axis in the solid state (Figures and ). The Ag–Ag distances within the Ag3 units (3.0016(2) and 3.0455(2) Å, respectively) are elongated by only 0.05 Å when compared to 4b, and the Ag1–Ag2–Ag3 bond angle is decreased to 163.268(3)°. The most prominent deviation from the structure of 4b is thealmost doubleddistance between two distinct Ag3 units of 6.2566(5) Å. Hence, in this case, argentophilic interactions between two adjacent Ag3 units can be neglected, at least in the solid state.

elements.content: Another difference compared to 4b is an additional acetonitrile molecule, which is present in the asymmetric unit and leads to a different coordination sphere of the central silver atom of the Ag3 unit. This silver atom is now situated in a strongly distorted octahedral environment bearing two cis orientated acetonitrile ligands and two pyridyl units of different ligand molecules on the equatorial positions and the two terminal silver atoms on the apical positions (Figure ). Like in 4b, the terminal silver atoms in 4d are coordinated by the central silver atom, one carbene of the ligand already coordinating the central silver atom, and one carbene and one pyridyl unit of another ligand molecule in a distorted sawhorse geometry (Figure ). The carbenes are situated trans to each other, with slightly smaller C–Ag–C angles of 176.805(4)° and 170.065(5)° than those found in 4b, and exhibit Ag–C bond lengths between 2.0806(1) and 2.1007(1) Å. Again, these distances are within the expected range for Ag–C bond lengths.

elements.content: Contrary to complexes 4a, 4b, and 4d, the structural analysis of single crystals of complexes 4c and 4e comprises separated Ag2 units. In both cases, these units are coordinated by two ligands to give cationic fragments of the general composition Ag2L2. Hereby, one of the ligands is coordinating in a bidentate fashion, employing only the carbene donors, whereas the second ligand is coordinating via all four donor sites (Figure ). The Ag–C bond lengths found for 4c (2.103(2)–2.115(2) Å) and 4e (2.090(3)–2.121(3) Å) are also comparable to known silver­(I) NHC bond lengths. The C–Ag–C axes of 4c and 4e are twisted against each other, which forces the ligands to adopt a bent structure as well. This coordination mode accounts for two almost planar halves of the complex, each centered by one silver atom, and interconnected by the alkylene bridges of the ligands (Figure ).

elements.content: Despite all of these similarities, a striking difference between the two complexes becomes obvious when the Ag–Ag distance is taken into account. While the distance of 4.5217(1) Å found for 4e is more than 1 Å longer than the sum of the atoms’ van der Waals radii, the Ag–Ag distance in 4c is only 2.85 Å. This calls for a rather strong argentophilic interaction between those silver centers, which can be seen in the distortion of the originally linear C–Ag–C axes. The C–Ag–C bond angles diminished to 170.60(8)° and 173.01(7)°, respectively, with the silver centers pointing toward each other.

elements.content: An intermediate structure to those described for 4b–4e is found for 4f. In this structure, two distinct Ag2 units are connected by a stretched, single ligand (Figure ). Within the Ag2 units, one of the silver atoms is three-coordinated by one carbene and one pyridine donor of the bridging ligand and one carbene position of another ligand molecule, whose remaining three donor sites are coordinating the second silver atom in a T-shaped fashion. This results in a twisted conformation of the two coordination axes C–Ag–C and C–Ag–N toward each other, which is found for complexes 4c and 4e as well. The slight distortion of these axes is caused by an argentophilic interaction between the two silver centers, which is manifested in a rather short Ag–Ag distance of only 2.8895(6) Å. The observed Ag–C distances are slightly shorter than those found for the congeners 4a–e, but still in the range of previously published Ag–C distances.

elements.content: A rationale for this somehow unexpected solid-state structure of compound 4f may be found in the length of the ligand’s alkylene bridge. On the one hand, the bulkiness of the ligands’ hexylene bridges impedes the coordination of two ligand molecules to the Ag2 units, hence leading to interconnected silver units. On the other hand, a hexylene bridge is both flexible and long enough to overcome the steric congestion found for the butylene bridges of 4d, and even more so the ethylene bridges of 4b, which cannot facilitate the formation of an Ag2 unit with closely neighbored silver centers due to steric restraints.

elements.content: The silver­(I) NHC complexes 4a–f exhibit similar UV/vis spectra in acetonitrile solution at ambient temperature (see Figures S28, S30, ). These are characterized by an intense absorption at λ = 195 nm with molar extinction coefficients in the range of 45 000 L·mol–1·cm–1 (4c, 4d) to 120 000 L·mol–1·cm–1 (4f), allowing for the assumption of spin-allowed, ligand-centered (LC) transitions (see Table ). Moreover, the assignment to LC transitions is backed by comparison with the UV/vis spectra of the corresponding bisimidazolium salts 3a–d (see Figure S29, ). Additionally, the spectra show a second, much broader absorption band at λ ≈ 215 nm, which displays shoulders at λ ≈ 250 nm and λ ≈ 270 nm, respectively. Interestingly, only the main absorption and the second shoulder are found in the spectra of the bisimidazolium salts as well, rationalizing their assignment to an LC transition. Hence, the shoulder at roughly 250 nm might be derived either from an absorption due to a metal–metal interaction or from a metal–ligand interaction. Contrary to the other spectra, the spectrum of the propylene bridged complex 4c shows an additional, very weak absorption at λ ≈ 315 nm, which might also be assigned to a transition with metal contributions, as there is no such absorption observed for 3c.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Spectroscopy

The silver(I) NHC complexes 4a-f exhibit similar UV/vis spectra in acetonitrile solution at ambient temperature (see Figures S28, S30, ). These are characterized by an intense absorption at λ = 195 nm with molar extinction coefficients in the range of 45000 L⋅mol-1⋅cm-1 (4c, 4d) to 120000 L⋅mol-1⋅cm-1 (4f), allowing for the assumption of spin-allowed, ligand-centered (LC) transitions (see Table ). Moreover, the assignment to LC transitions is backed by comparison with the UV/vis spectra of the corresponding bisimidazolium salts 3a-d (see Figure S29, ). Additionally, the spectra show a second, much broader absorption band at λ ~ 215 nm, which displays shoulders at λ ~ 250 nm and λ ~ 270 nm, respectively. Interestingly, only the main absorption and the second shoulder are found in the spectra of the bisimidazolium salts as well, rationalizing their assignment to an LC transition. Hence, the shoulder at roughly 250 nm might be derived either from an absorption due to a metal-metal interaction or from a metal-ligand interaction. Contrary to the other spectra, the spectrum of the propylene bridged complex 4c shows an additional, very weak absorption at λ ~ 315 nm, which might also be assigned to a transition with metal contributions, as there is no such absorption observed for 3c.

The photoluminescence characteristics of complexes 4a–f are examined at room temperature in both, the solid state and in dilute acetonitrile solutions (≈10 mM). Upon pulsed excitation at λ = 337 nm, all complexes show unstructured emissions (Figure and Figures S31–S36, ), which exhibit significant Stokes shifts when compared to the absorption spectra (Table ). While the emission intensities are high in the solid state, the solutions of complexes 4a–f display mostly less intense emissions. In either case, the main contribution to the detected emission exhibits lifetimes of approximately 10–15 μs (4b–f), and approximately 35 μs (4a). This allowstogether with the likeliness of intersystem crossing events due to the high spin–orbit coupling of the silver­(I) ionsfor the assumption of them being most likely phosphorescent in nature (Table ). This is also supported by the observed Stokes shifts, which are most often indicative for charge-transfer processes originating in excited triplet states. Contributions with lifetimes shorter than 10 ns, which are possibly fluorescent in nature, are observed for complexes 4a, 4e, and 4f in the solid state and for 4d–f in solution (Table ). In general, these contributions are of minor importance and exhibit barely 5% of the intensity of the phosphorescent contribution.

elements.content: Most interestingly, the phosphorescent solid-state emissions of complexes 4b and 4d–f as well as the phosphorescent emissions observed for solutions of 4a, 4d, and 4f disaggregate further into a prompt emission and a delayed emission, which shows a substantial red shift of up to 90 nm (Table ). These delayed emissions could possibly be assigned to either metal-to-ligand charge-transfer or metal-to-metal charge-transfer processes.
elements.clean_text: Most interestingly, the phosphorescent solid-state emissions of complexes 4b and 4d-f as well as the phosphorescent emissions observed for solutions of 4a, 4d, and 4f disaggregate further into a prompt emission and a delayed emission, which shows a substantial red shift of up to 90 nm (Table ). These delayed emissions could possibly be assigned to either metal-to-ligand charge-transfer or metal-to-metal charge-transfer processes.

elements.content: Due to the mostly phosphorescent nature of the emissions with lifetimes between 2 and 37 μs as well as their comparatively high intensities, the complexes 4a–f can be used as lead structures for the development of other light-emitting silver­(I) NHC complexes. The observed emission lifetimes not only are comparable to those of other transition-metal complexes used in OLEDs but also allow for the assumption that saturation effects would be of minor importance only. Moreover, the argentophilic interactions, which are found in the solid-state structures of all but one (4e) complex, apparently play a crucial role for the observed photoemission. Though they most likely do not directly contribute to the emission via metal-to-metal transitions, the close proximity of the silver centers is likely to enhance intersystem crossing of the excited singlet state into the triplet state, which ultimately leads to the observed high emission intensities. Hence, for further light-emitting silver­(I) NHC complexes, the general design should maintain silver–silver interactions. Tuning of emission wavelengths should be accomplished by modifying the ligands’ backbone or wingtip substituents in order to affect the frontier orbitals and subsequently the emission characteristics.

Tuning of emission wavelengths should be accomplished by modifying the ligands' backbone or wingtip substituents in order to affect the frontier orbitals and subsequently the emission characteristics.

elements.content: Cyclic voltammetry of complexes 4a–f reveals that the electronic properties of these complexes are very similar (see Tables S7–S12 and Figures S37–S42, ). All complexes 4 exhibit an intense set of signals attributable to a quasi-reversible process, which can be detected at a potential of E P A = +476 mV and E P C = +94 mV (ν = 100 mV/s), respectively. Additionally, irreversible oxidation processes are observed in all but one (4d) case (Figure S40, ). Comparison with cyclic voltammograms of the bisimidazolium salts 3a–f reveals counterpart processes to quasi-reversible processes detected at roughly E P A ≈ −1 V (ν = 100 mV/s). Hence, these are most likely ligand-centered processes. No counterparts are detected for the other processes, indicating that those are features, which are derived from the formation of complexes 4a–f. Furthermore, the similarity of the cyclic voltammograms obtained for complexes 4a–f allows the assumption that the electronic properties of complexes 4a–f are defined largely by the ligand and do not depend on the number of silver cations present in the complex nor on their interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Cyclic Voltammetry

Cyclic voltammetry of complexes 4a-f reveals that the electronic properties of these complexes are very similar (see Tables S7-S12 and Figures S37-S42, ). All complexes 4 exhibit an intense set of signals attributable to a quasi-reversible process, which can be detected at a potential of E P A = +476 mV and E P C = +94 mV (ν = 100 mV/s), respectively. Additionally, irreversible oxidation processes are observed in all but one (4d) case (Figure S40, ). Comparison with cyclic voltammograms of the bisimidazolium salts 3a-f reveals counterpart processes to quasi-reversible processes detected at roughly E P A ~ -1 V (ν = 100 mV/s). Hence, these are most likely ligand-centered processes. No counterparts are detected for the other processes, indicating that those are features, which are derived from the formation of complexes 4a-f. Furthermore, the similarity of the cyclic voltammograms obtained for complexes 4a-f allows the assumption that the electronic properties of complexes 4a-f are defined largely by the ligand and do not depend on the number of silver cations present in the complex nor on their interaction.

elements.content: The synthesis of new silver­(I) carbene complexes bearing tetradentate NCCN ligands of the alkylenebimpy-type with lengths of the bridging alkylene unit ranging from ethylene to hexylene is described. The obtained silver­(I) complexes exhibit a surprisingly wide structural diversity and led to the discovery of the very first infinite chain of almost linear Ag3 units within a cage of helical ligand molecules. Structures of a similar type were before only known for mixed Ag/Au complexes bearing a related bidentate or tridentate, mono-NHC ligand, as well as the figure-of-eight Ir and Rh complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The synthesis of new silver(I) carbene complexes bearing tetradentate NCCN ligands of the alkylenebimpy-type with lengths of the bridging alkylene unit ranging from ethylene to hexylene is described. The obtained silver(I) complexes exhibit a surprisingly wide structural diversity and led to the discovery of the very first infinite chain of almost linear Ag3 units within a cage of helical ligand molecules. Structures of a similar type were before only known for mixed Ag/Au complexes bearing a related bidentate or tridentate, mono-NHC ligand, as well as the figure-of-eight Ir and Rh complexes.

elements.content: The photoluminescence properties of the synthesized complexes have been evaluated after pulsed laser excitation of solid samples and dilute solutions of the complexes at room temperature. The complexes 4a–f unanimously exhibit luminescence that is mostly phosphorescent with lifetimes of up to 37 μs. Fluorescent contributions are only of minor importance.

The complexes 4a-f unanimously exhibit luminescence that is mostly phosphorescent with lifetimes of up to 37 μs. Fluorescent contributions are only of minor importance.

elements.content: All complexes emit blue to green light with comparatively broad emission bands in the region between λ = 420 nm and λ = 510 nm. On the basis of these findings, the complexes 4a–f may be used as a starting point for the development of similar complexes that are suitable for the manufacturing of organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs).

Moreover, complexes 4b–f might serve as precursors for the synthesis of NCCN complexes of other transition metals.

Experimental Section

All reactions were carried out under ambient conditions unless mentioned otherwise. Solvents were purified by distillation over sodium sulfate. Deuterated solvents were used as obtained.

[Bis-acetonitrile-bis­(1,1′-methylene-bis­(3,3′-(pyrid-2-yl)-imida­zolin-2,2′-diylidene))­trissilver­(I)] Tris­(hexa­fluoro­phosphate) (<bold>4a</bold>)

A slurry of 3a (178 mg, 300 μmol) and Ag2O (464 mg, 2.00 mmol) in MeCN (10 mL) was stirred for 19 h at r.t. under exclusion of light. Afterward, the remaining Ag2O was removed by filtration over a pad of Celite. The resulting yellowish solution was concentrated to ∼2 mL before Et2O was added to precipitate the product as a white, flaky solid. The solid was isolated, washed with Et2O (3 × 5 mL), and dried under reduced pressure to yield 4a as an off-white solid. Yield: 120 mg (86 μmol, 57%). 1H NMR (CD3CN, 300 K) δ (ppm) = 7.97 (ddd, 4H, 3 J HH = 4.9 Hz, 4 J HH = 1.9 Hz, 5 J HH = 0.9 Hz, pyr-H), 7.88 (d, 4H, 3 J HH = 2.1 Hz, Im-H), 7.79 (ddd, 4H, 3 J HH = 8.3, 7.5 Hz, 4 J HH = 1.8 Hz, pyr-H), 7.75 (d, 4H, 3 J HH = 2.1 Hz, Im-H), 7.62 (ddd, 4H, 3 J HH = 8.2 Hz, 4 J HH = 1.0 Hz, pyr-H), 7.26 (ddd, 4H, 3 J HH = 7.5, 4.9 Hz, 4 J HH = 0.9 Hz, pyr-H), 6.65 (s, 4H, N-CH2-N), 1.96 (s, 3H, NC-CH3). 13C NMR (CD3CN, 300 K) δ (ppm) = 183.94, 151.25, 149.99, 141.42, 125.65, 124.23, 122.38, 116.56, 67.56. 31P NMR (CD3CN, 300 K) δ (ppm) = −144.59 (sept., PF6 –).

Moreover, complexes 4b–f might serve as precursors for the synthesis of NCCN complexes of other transition metals.

Experimental Section

All reactions were carried out under ambient conditions unless mentioned otherwise. Solvents were purified by distillation over sodium sulfate. Deuterated solvents were used as obtained.

Moreover, complexes 4b-f might serve as precursors for the synthesis of NCCN complexes of other transition metals.

Experimental Section

All reactions were carried out under ambient conditions unless mentioned otherwise. Solvents were purified by distillation over sodium sulfate. Deuterated solvents were used as obtained.

[Bis-acetonitrile-bis(1,1'-methylene-bis(3,3'-(pyrid-2-yl)-imidazolin-2,2'-diylidene))trissilver(I)] Tris(hexafluorophosphate) (4a)

Afterward, the remaining Ag2O was removed by filtration over a pad of Celite. The resulting yellowish solution was concentrated to ~2 mL before Et2O was added to precipitate the product as a white, flaky solid. The solid was isolated, washed with Et2O (3 × 5 mL), and dried under reduced pressure to yield 4a as an off-white solid.
